discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Correct answer is A.
All other options have incorrect syntax.

You can't configure 'dial-peer voice' under 'config-class'. Which makes me think that there is no valid answer here.

LocalGateway(config-class)#voice class codec 10
LocalGateway(config-class)#?
VOICECLASS configuration commands:
 codec Set class codec parameters
 exit Exit from voice class configuration mode
 help Description of the interactive help system
 no Negate a command or set its defaults
 video Video setup for voice class

Selected Answer: A
It's A. The router in D is in enable mode and it is not correct.

Selected Answer: A
Wrong it's A.
It's all about Command Prompt :)

questions.question_text: An organization is deploying a Cisco Unified Border Element for Webex calling. The engineer's voice gateway is a Cisco CSR1000v on version 17.x.x. How must the engineer configure G.729 codec to be the first priority for all calls, followed by G.711ulaw and G.711alaw?

choices.C: secure TLS connection and SIP certificates
choices.D: TCP connection using port 5061 with explicit TLS1.2 and signed SIP certificates
choices.B: secure TLS connection and Tomcat certificates
choices.A: TCP connection using port 5061 with explicit TLS1.2 and ACME-signed SIP certificates

questions.question_text: An engineer is setting up a new voicemail server, and the requirements state that the integration for call control must be secure. During the configuration the engineer wants to select “Next Generation Encryption”. What is the prerequisite for using this option to ensure an encrypted SIP integration?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
based on link, response B:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/unified-communications/unity-connection/211622-Configuration-Example-for-Secure-SIP-Int.html#anc19

• C. Cisco Unified Border Element is not sending any support for DTMF. DTMF configuration must be added to the appropriate dial peer: Correct. If the Cisco Unified Border Element (CUBE) is not properly configured to handle DTMF signals, the digits pressed by callers will not be transmitted to Cisco Unity Connection, causing the menu prompts to fail.
In the INVITE there isn't any DTMF allowed, so the DTMF will not work. This is the issue.
In the INVITE there isn't any DTMF allowed, so the DTMF will not work. This is the issue.
Anyone has a explenation for this question?

comments.content:
Yea, there’s no attribute for DTMF

m = audio 35904 RTP/AVP 8 101
a = rtpmap:8 PCMA/8000
a = rtpmap:101 telephone-event/8000

101 being the DTMF attribute ETC

choices.D: The Cisco Unity Connection Call Handler is configured for a ג€Release to Switchג€ transfer type. Transfers must be disabled for the Cisco Unity Connection Call Handler.
choices.C: Cisco Unified Border Element is not sending any support for DTMF. DTMF configuration must be added to the appropriate dial peer.
choices.B: Cisco Unity Connection is configured on G.729 only. Cisco Unity Connection must be reconfigured to support iLBC.
choices.A: Cisco Unified Border Element is sending the incorrect media IP address. The IP address of the loopback interface must be advertised in the SDP.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Calls to Cisco Unity Connection are failing across Cisco Unified Border Element when callers try to select a menu prompt. Why is this happening and how is it fixed?
How does an administrator change the DNS settings on Cisco UCM?

choices.A: Find the DNS setting in the system parameter settings in the Network section
choices.B: Go to System > Network > DNS settings
choices.C: Go to Network > IP > Cisco Serviceability and change the DNS settings
choices.D: Open an SSH session to each node in the Cisco UCM cluster and change the DNS setting using CLI

questions.question_text: An engineer is configuring LLQ in a network and completes the section for identifying different DSCP markings. Which part of the configuration specifies the traffic class for LLQ?

discussion.content:
The steps generally follow this sequence:

Class map: Define and match the traffic.
Policy map: Apply queuing and priority behavior, such as LLQ.
Service policy: Apply the policy map to an interface.

Based on the detailed configuration process, the part of the configuration that specifies the traffic class for LLQ is:

A. class map

The class map defines and identifies traffic classes, which are then referenced in the policy map where specific Quality of Service (QoS) actions, such as Low Latency Queueing (LLQ), are applied
i think its A as you need policy map as top end then class map configure or modify policy to select class

Selected Answer: B
I believe it should be B, policy-map, per this document:

SUMMARY STEPS

 enable
 configure terminal
 policy-map policy-map
 class {class-name | class-default }
 priority {bandwidth-kbps | percent percentage } [burst ]
 bandwidth {bandwidth-kbps | percent percentage | remaining percent percentage }
 end

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/qos_conmgt/configuration/xe-16-12/qos-conmgt-xe-16-12-book/qos-conmgt-llq-pps.html
